author: Kristin Wong
title: These Index Funds Make It Easy to Invest in Socially Responsible Companies
text:
Stats show that consumers want to support companies that support social and environmental issues . If you want to invest in socially responsible companies, too, Business Insider points to a handful of index funds that can help you get started.
We’ve explained how index fund investing works before. In simple terms, an index fund is a group of individual assets, like companies, that you can invest in all at once. Index funds are a great way for newbie investors to get started . While you want a broad, diverse portfolio, you may also want to invest in specific types of companies that support things like sustainability and fair trade.

If so, here are some specific funds you can look into, as Business Insider’s Gus Lubin explains:
General funds : “There’s VFTSX , which tracks US companies that rate highly on social, human rights, and environmental criteria, at a 0.22% expense ratio. Its largest holdings include Apple, Microsoft, and Alphabet. Outside the US, ESGD tracks companies in developed with high environmental, social, and governance scores, at a 0.40% expense ratio.”
Renewable energy : “...consider QCLN , which tracks green companies on the NASDAQ, with the largest holding in Tesla. GEX is a similar option that has more global exposure (Tesla is the second-largest holding). ICLN is an option with lots of emerging market exposure.”
Gender diversity : “...try SHE , which tracks big US companies that are leaders in gender diversity, at a 0.20% expense ratio. Its largest holdings include Pfizer, PepsiCo, Amgen, and 3M.”
Of course, the investing firm that manages a fund ultimately picks the companies, so you’re at the mercy of their discretion. It’s always worth looking into the fund’s holdings (the companies it tracks) yourself, and you can do that using a stock tool like Google Finance. You’ll want to look up the fund’s expense ratio, too , which is basically the fee that comes with it.
